{{Infobox person |name = Jason Sweeney |birth_name = Jason Keel Sweeney |birth_date = July 29, 1986<ref name=dale>{{cite news |last=Dale |first=Maryclaire |date=2003-06-19 |title=Philadelphia Teen's Brutal Beating Death Called 'Something Out of the Dark Ages' |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1988&dat=20030619&id=J3AiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K60FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1459,4472673&hl=en |newspaper=[[Argus-Press]] | location=[[Owosso, Michigan]] |page=10 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=2016-01-21 |quote=[Jason] had been working there...with plans to join the Navy when he turned 17 next month. }}</ref> |birth_place = [[Fishtown, Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] |death_date = May 30, 2003 (age 16)<ref name=dale /> |death_place = [[Fishtown, Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] |death_cause = Murder |image =Jasonsweeney.jpg |caption = Jason Sweeney c. 2003 |signature = |parents = Paul and Dawn Sweeney |spouse = |children = |occupation = Construction worker |movement = |organization = |monuments = |alma_mater = |awards = |religion = |denomination = }}
'''Jason Keel Sweeney''' was a [[construction worker]] from [[Fishtown, Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], who at the age of 16 was [[murder]]ed by four teenagers for his paycheck on May 30, 2003. The perpetrators included a girl he was dating and his best friend since childhood. Due to the manner in which Sweeney was murdered, the ages of the teens involved, and the seeming indifference of the perpetrators, the crime received national media coverage.<ref name=abc>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2003-06-25 |title=Manson Echo in Philly Teen Murder Case |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=125030&page=1 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |website=abcnews.go.com |deadurl=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131114323/http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=125030&page=1 |archive-date=2011-01-31 |access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref>
==Murder== Jason Sweeney had left school and was working for his father, a contractor, on a building project in [[Philadelphia]]. He had recently met a girl he liked, 15-year-old Justina Morley, with whom he had a date on the evening of Friday, May 30, 2003. Unbeknownst to Sweeney, Morley was regularly engaging in sexual relations with two other 16-year-olds, Nicholas Coia and Edward Batzig Jr.<ref name=Ramsland>{{cite news|last=Ramsland|first=Katherine|title=Justina Morley's art of persuasion|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-03-18/news/25418839_1_psychopaths-jason-sweeney-traits/2|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2005-03-18|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref> Batzig had been Sweeney's best friend since the fourth grade. Nicholas Coia and his 17-year-old brother, Domenic Coia, had also been friendly with Sweeney, but the brothers later ended the friendship.<ref name=schaffer>{{cite news|last1=Schaffer|first1=Michael Currie|last2=Soteropoulos|first2=Jacqueline|title=In Fishtown, Lives Fatefully Linked: Fiercely Loyal to Each Other, Brothers Guarded Their Own 'Little World'|url=http://articles.philly.com/2003-06-22/news/25448571_1_jason-sweeney-brothers-friends|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2003-06-22|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref>
With the promise of sex, Morley lured Sweeney to "The Trails," a wooded area of [[Fishtown, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Fishtown]] near the [[Delaware River]], where Batzig and the Coia brothers were lying in wait. Batzig took the first blow, striking Sweeney in the head 4 to 5 times.<ref name=Soteropoulos030105>{{cite news|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Jurors hear of teen's final moments|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-03-01/news/25420338_1_jurors-parochial-school-jason-sweeney|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2005-03-01|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref> Batzig and the Coia brothers then pummeled Sweeney, primarily on his head and face, with a hatchet, a hammer and a rock until he was dead. Batzig later told a detective how he hit Sweeney with the hatchet face four or five times. Batzig said, "Jason started begging for his life, but we just kept hitting him."<ref name=Zucchino /> Batzig also said that Sweeney looked at him during the beating and said "Please stop, I'm bleeding," after which Batzig hit Sweeney again with the axe.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} They finished by dropping a boulder rock on the right side of his head.<ref name=killerkidsada>{{cite episode |title=Foul Ball and Framed |series=[[Killer Kids]] |date=2012-11-26 |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/killer-kids/video/full-episodes |network=[[LMN (TV channel)|LMN]] |season=1 (LMN) |number=1 |last=Conroy |first=Jude (Assistant District Attorney)}}</ref> Sweeney's head was crushed and the only bone left undamaged was his left cheekbone.<ref name=Soteropoulos61803>{{cite news|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Tale of teen's betrayal|url=http://articles.philly.com/2003-06-18/news/25448761_1_penalty-bloody-clothes-jason-sweeney|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2003-06-18|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref> He was identified by a cut on his hand that he sustained at his construction job.{{citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=May 2016}}
Following Sweeney's murder, the four assailants stole the $500 cash he had earned from work.<ref name=killerkidsada /> Before leaving the crime scene, the Coias, Batzig and Morley shared a group hug and split the money, which they used to buy jewelry and illegal drugs—[[heroin]], [[marijuana]] and [[Xanax]]—and then "partied beyond redemption," according to Domenic.<ref name=Zucchino>{{cite news |last=Zucchino|first=David|title=Slaying of a Teen Leaves City Stunned|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jun/26/nation/na-helter26|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|location=[[Los Angeles, California]]|date=2003-06-26|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref><ref name=Soteropoulos112103>{{cite news|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Adult trial in Fishtown beating|url=http://articles.philly.com/2003-11-21/news/25461831_1_juvenile-court-adult-court-death-penalty/2|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2003-11-21|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref>
Domenic Coia confessed in a court hearing that they were all involved in the murder of Sweeney. The police said the murder was planned days before. Part of the preparation of the murder was listening to the [[The Beatles|Beatles]] song "[[Helter Skelter (song)|Helter Skelter]]" over forty times, prompting later news coverage to draw a parallel to the [[Charles Manson|Manson family murders]].<ref name=abc /><ref name=Zucchino /> Joshua Staab, 18, a friend of Domenic Coia, said that the group had bragged about their plan to kill Sweeney by using Justina Morley as "bait." Staab also said that Batzig knew that Sweeney would have his paycheck earnings on him on the day of the murder. The prosecutor asked Staab about the teens' demeanor after the killing. Staab said, "They seemed pretty fine. In a way, happy."<ref name=Zucchino />
Although all four teens involved in the murder were drug addicts, they were not high before they murdered Sweeney. In response to a detective's question about whether they were high during the killing, Domenic Coia answered, "No, I was as sober as I am now. It is sick, isn't it?"<ref name=Zucchino /> A detective involved in the case and a forensic psychologist later opined that the killers' motivation went beyond robbery and stemmed from envy and resentment of Sweeney's relative success in life.<ref name=killerkidsexperts>{{cite episode |title=Foul Ball and Framed |series=[[Killer Kids]] |date=2012-11-26 |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/killer-kids/video/full-episodes |network=[[LMN (TV channel)|LMN]] |season=1 (LMN) |number=1 |last1=Skoler |first=Glen, Dr. (Forensic Psychologist)|last2=Reinhold |first2=Richard (Detective, Philadelphia Police Dept.}}</ref>
==Justina Morley==
Justina Morley claimed that she started smoking marijuana at the age of 10, and shortly thereafter started taking prescription pills and snorting [[cocaine]]. April Frederick, Morley's mother, said her daughter started cutting her wrists at the age of 10. Morley had been hospitalized for threatening [[suicide]] and [[self-mutilation]] in 2002. She was once admitted to [[Friends Hospital]] for cutting her wrists, knees and thighs, taking pills and displaying a suicide poem, which she had penned, on her door. Morley told her mother that she would commit suicide if her mother did not take her out of the hospital; her mother then took her out against the hospital's advice. Morley had also been expelled from public school in the eighth grade, which she then repeated at the private Holy Name of Jesus Catholic school in Fishtown.
A psychiatrist hired by the defense team, William Russell, said the reason Morley began sexual activity at an early age "was an attempt at validation of self-worth". Morley testified that she had sex with both Nicholas Coia and Batzig in exchange for heroin just a few days before they murdered Sweeney.<ref name=Burling>{{cite news|last1=Soteropoulos |first1=Jacqueline | last2=Burling|first2=Stacey|title=Morley's Descent Began at Tender Age |url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-03-20/news/25420402_1_cross-examination-teenage-accomplices-testimony|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]| location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]| date=2005-03-20|accessdate=2016-01-17}}</ref>
==Trial== Justina Morley's attorneys explained to the judge that the girl had suffered through depression, suicide attempts and substance abuse in order to get her a juvenile court trial. Psychiatrist William Russell explained to the court how Morley attempted suicide twice by overdosing on pills only the year before the killing. Morley's attorney argued she was the least culpable and if tried as a juvenile, she could get treatment and live a productive life. The Assistant District Attorney argued that Morley was an important part of the plot in Sweeney's murder and she had treatment before, to no avail. If tried in a [[juvenile court]], Morley could have been free of court supervision by the age of 21. The judge agreed with the prosecution and ordered her to be tried as an adult for murder.<ref name=Soteropoulos112103 /> At that point, Morley pleaded guilty to third-degree murder in exchange for her testimony against other defendants, and was sentenced to 17 1/2 to 35 years in prison.<ref name=Soteropoulos030105 />
Domenic Coia, Nicholas Coia and Edward Batzig Jr. were charged with [[Murder (United States law)|first-degree murder]], [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]], robbery and possessing an instrument of crime. All were tried together as adults. In 2004, prosecutors decided not to seek the death penalty against Batzig and Nicholas Coia, but planned to seek it against Domenic Coia.<ref name=Soteropoulos040110>{{cite news|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Teens' Execution Won't Be Sought: Prosecutors Decline to Say Why They Changed Their Strategy About the Trial of Two Defendants in Last Year's Fishtown Murder|url=http://articles.philly.com/2004-01-10/news/25366482_1_death-penalty-prosecutors-juvenile-law-center|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2004-01-10|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref> However, during the trial, the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] ruled in ''[[Roper v. Simmons]]''<ref>''[[Roper v. Simmons]]'', 543 U.S. 551 (2005).</ref> that defendants under the age of 18 could not be executed.<ref name=lane>{{cite news|last=Lane|first=Charles|title=5-4 Supreme Court Abolishes Juvenile Executions |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A62584-2005Mar1.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=2005-03-02|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref> As a result, Domenic Coia, who was 14 days away from his 18th birthday at the time of the crime, could not receive the death penalty. Therefore, the Coia brothers and Batzig all faced mandatory life sentences without parole if convicted of first-degree murder.<ref name=Soteropoulos030205>{{cite news|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Girl describes beating death of Fishtown's Jason Sweeney|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-03-02/news/25418675_1_death-penalty-key-witness-first-degree-murder/2|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2005-03-02|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref><ref name=Soteropoulos031005>{{cite web|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Teen Trio Convicted In Fishtown Murder|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-03-10/news/25419047_1_prosecutor-and-defense-attorneys-jury-foreman-jury-of-eight-men/2|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2005-03-10|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref>
Jailhouse letters of the defendants were read during the trial to understand their behavior and to determine who, if anyone, was the most culpable. Defense counsel for the Coias and Batzig argued that Morley was the instigator and led the boys to commit the murder of Sweeney. In one of her writings to Domenic Coia, she wrote: "So you say I'm manipulative, and yes, I believe I am in ways. I'm persuasively manipulative, and I think I'm pretty good at it, too. I enjoy dragging people along." She went on to say: ". . . Tell me you don't enjoy these gullible humans. It's funny how easy it is to persuade them into lies."<ref name=Soteropoulos030305>{{cite news|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=Fishtown witness attacked on letters|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-03-03/news/25420987_1_master-manipulator-jailhouse-letter-trial-testimony|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2005-03-03|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref> She also wrote to Domenic Coia, "I'm a cold-blooded [expletive] death-worshiping bitch who survives by feeding off the weak and lonely. I lure them, and then I crush them."<ref name=Soteropoulos031005 /> Expressing no remorse at all in one letter, she stated: "I am guilty. But I still don't feel guilty for anything. . . . I still enjoy my flashbacks. They give me comfort. I love them."<ref name=Soteropoulos030205 /> However, Morley testified that she did feel remorse for the slaying of Sweeney and that she only wrote such things so that she would be accepted by the Coias and Batzig.<ref name=Soteropoulos030305 /> The prosecution, while acknowledging that Morley's letters showed her to be "a cold-blooded killer", nevertheless used her letters to demonstrate the depravity of the group.<ref name=Soteropoulos031005 />
The defense attorneys for the Coias and Batzig also contended that their clients, being drug addicts, lacked the intent to kill needed to support a first-degree murder conviction, and at most had committed the lesser crime of [[third-degree murder]]. However, this strategy was undermined by the confessions of the three defendants. Assistant District Attorney Jude Conroy read part of Domenic Coia's confession in court: "We just kept hitting and hitting him. . . . We took Sweeney's wallet and split up the money, and we partied beyond redemption."<ref name=Soteropoulos030105 /> Domenic Coia had also told a detective: "It was like we were all happy [with] what we did."<ref name=Soteropoulos031005 />
==Verdict and sentencing== The Coia brothers and Batzig were convicted on charges of first-degree murder, conspiracy, robbery and possession of an instrument of crime. In May 2005, each one was sentenced to mandatory [[life in prison without parole]] for murder, plus 22 1/2 to 45 years for conspiracy, robbery and possessing an instrument of crime.
None of the teens showed any remorse or apologized for the murder. Paul Sweeney, the victim's father, addressed Domenic Coia, saying, "Look at me, Domenic, with your evil eyes". Domenic Coia responded, "I never thought I had evil eyes, but I guess I do. And I'm cool." The judge, in denying defense counsel's motion for a sentence that could allow for parole, said: "There is a level of inhumanity that exists in these facts. This was a totally depraved act."<ref name=soteropoulos050705>{{cite web|last=Soteropoulos|first=Jacqueline|title=3 Fishtown teens get life sentences|url=http://articles.philly.com/2005-05-07/news/25439621_1_life-sentences-jason-sweeney-savage-death|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2005-05-07|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref>
==Resentencing== In 2012, the Supreme Court in ''[[Miller v. Alabama]]''<ref>''Miller v. Alabama'', 567 U.S. ____ (2012).</ref> struck down mandatory life without parole sentences for juveniles under 18, holding that the court must consider the individual circumstances of each juvenile defendant in determining sentence — which might still be life without parole if, in the court's judgment, the circumstances warrant it.<ref name=Rovner>{{cite journal |last=Rovner |first=Joshua |date=October 2015 |title=Policy Brief: Juvenile Life Without Parole: An Overview |url=http://sentencingproject.org/doc/publications/jj_Juvenile_Life_Without_Parole.pdf |journal=Briefing Paper |publisher=[[Sentencing Project|The Sentencing Project]] |page=1 |access-date=16 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=lee>{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Suevon |date=2012-08-02 |title=Despite Supreme Court Ruling, Many Minors May Stay In Prison For Life |url=https://www.propublica.org/article/despite-supreme-court-ruling-many-minors-may-stay-in-prison-for-life |newspaper=[[ProPublica]] |location=[[New York City]] |access-date=2016-01-17 }}</ref> The Supreme Court left open the question of whether ''Miller'' applied retroactively to trigger resentencing of all juveniles who had already been sentenced, leaving this to the decision of individual state courts and legislatures.<ref name=lee /> In Pennsylvania, where the Coias and Batzig were sentenced, the state supreme court ruled in 2013 not to apply ''Miller'' retroactively, thus upholding the mandatory life sentences of juveniles whose sentences were already final at the time of the Supreme Court ruling.<ref name="lee"/><ref>Rovner, p. [http://sentencingproject.org/doc/publications/jj_Juvenile_Life_Without_Parole.pdf 3].</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Palattella |first=Ed |date=2014-12-21 |title=U.S. Supreme Court to Review Juvenile 'Lifer' Ruling |url=http://www.goerie.com/article/20141221/NEWS02/312219930/us-supreme-court-to-review-juvenile-lifer-ruling |newspaper=[[Erie Times-News]] |location=[[Erie, Pennsylvania]]|dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918232624/http://www.goerie.com/article/20141221/NEWS02/312219930/us-supreme-court-to-review-juvenile-lifer-ruling |archive-date=2015-09-18 |access-date=2016-01-17 }}</ref> However, the state supreme court also ruled (in a different case) that juveniles sentenced to mandatory life without parole whose sentences were not yet final at the time of ''Miller'' were entitled to a resentencing hearing considering their individual circumstances, at which they could receive a sentence of life without parole, or life with the possibility of parole after a minimum term.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jlc.org/blog/juvenile-law-center-responds-pennsylvania-supreme-courts-ruling-commonwealth-v-batts |title=Juvenile Law Center Responds to Pennsylvania Supreme Court's Ruling in Commonwealth v. Batts |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2013-03-26 |website=JLC.org |publisher=[[Juvenile Law Center]] |access-date=2016-01-18 |quote=The decision in ''Commonwealth v. Batts'' applies to juveniles whose homicide convictions were still on appeal at the time the United States Supreme Court decided ''Miller v. Alabama''. }}</ref> Batzig and Nicholas Coia, who both had appeals pending at the time of ''Miller'', were granted such resentencing hearings.<ref>''[http://law.justia.com/cases/pennsylvania/supreme-court/2013/35-eal-2010.html Commonwealth v. Coia]'', No. 35 EAL 2010 (Pa. 2013) (per curiam).</ref><ref>''[http://law.justia.com/cases/pennsylvania/supreme-court/2013/131-eal-2010.html Commonwealth v. Batzig]'', No. 131 EAL 2010 (Pa. 2013) (per curiam).</ref>
At Nicholas Coia's resentencing hearing on February 19, 2015, Common Pleas Judge Sandy L. V. Byrd sentenced him to life in prison without the possibility of parole, upholding the original 2005 sentence. Byrd noted, "This is an uncommon case, there are no factors which remove the defendant from the punishment of life in prison without parole," Byrd said. "Not only did he plan the assault, but he participated in the assault which was so violent that Jason Sweeney had to be identified with dental records." <ref>{{cite news |last=Witt |first=Lara |date=2015-02-20 |title=Man Resentenced to Life Without Parole in the Brutal 2003 Slaying of Fishtown Teen |url=http://articles.philly.com/2015-02-20/news/59343539_1_jason-sweeney-nicholas-coia-edward-batzig-jr |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |access-date=2016-01-17 }}</ref>
==Memorial foundation== Paul and Dawn Sweeney, Jason Sweeney's parents, set up the [[Jason Keel Sweeney Foundation]], in memory of their son, to fund a full scholarship for the [[Valley Forge Military School]], the school of their son's dreams. Jason Sweeney had wanted to attend the military school to become a [[United States Navy SEALs|Navy SEAL]]. He had been accepted into the school, but could not afford the tuition. <ref name=Roy>{{cite news|last=Roy|first=Sree|title=Slain teen's scholarship fund is building: The family of Jason Sweeney wants to help send a boy to the school he wanted to attend but couldn't afford|url=http://articles.philly.com/2003-08-02/news/25455385_1_scholarship-fund-full-scholarship-jason-sweeney|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|location=[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]|date=2003-08-02|access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref>
==In popular culture== A 2003 episode of ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'' entitled "Coming of Rage" (Season 4, Episode 10) is loosely based on the crime.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ramsland |first=Katherine |date= |title=True Stories of C.S.I.: The Real Crimes Behind the Best Episodes of the Popular TV Show |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ocVCYi2lUwQC&pg=PA97#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=[[New York City]] |publisher=[[Berkley Books|Berkeley Boulevard Books]] |page=97 |isbn=978-0-425-22234-8}}</ref>
The crime inspired comic artist [[Kevin Colden]]'s 2008 graphic novel ''Fishtown'', which was nominated for an [[Eisner Award]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Ali|title=Smells Like Teen Carnage: A Philly Comics Writer Turns a Fishtown Murder Into Grim Art|url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/arts-and-culture/smells_like_teen_carnage-38427929.html|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Weekly]]|date=2007-06-20 |access-date=2016-01-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Umile |first=Domenic |date=2012-08-14 |title=A Dearth of Contrition in 'Fishtown' |url=http://www.popmatters.com/feature/161565-a-dearth-of-contrition-in-fishtown/ |magazine=[[PopMatters]] |publisher=Sarah Zupko|access-date=2016-01-17 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Zalben |first=Alex |date=2012-10-16 |title=Interview: Kevin Colden on the Re-Release of the Eisner Nominated 'Fishtown' |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2626902/kevin-colden-fishtown/ |publisher=[[MTV]] |website=MTV.com |access-date=2016-01-17 }}</ref>
A 2012, episode of the [[Lifetime Movie Network]] series ''[[Killer Kids]]'' entitled "Foul Ball and Framed" detailed the murder, including actual footage from the crime scene, in the second segment of the episode ("Framed").<ref name=killerkids>{{cite episode |title=Foul Ball and Framed |series=[[Killer Kids]] |date=2012-11-26 |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/killer-kids/video/full-episodes |network=[[LMN (TV channel)|LMN]] |season=1 (LMN) |number=1 }}</ref>
In 2013, convicted murderer Domenic Coia wrote a memoir of his life and the murder, entitled ''Biological Juvenile''. It was subsequently posted in PDF form on the website prisonsfoundation.org.<ref>{{cite book|last=Coia|first=Domenic|title=Biological Juvenile|url=http://prisonsfoundation.org/uploads/mem-biologicaljuv.pdf |date=2013-10-05|publisher=Unpublished book manuscript, posted on prisonsfoundation.org |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807215414/http://prisonsfoundation.org/uploads/mem-biologicaljuv.pdf|archive-date=2016-08-07|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref>
An episode of ''Murder Among Friends,'' titled '"Friend Fatale," on [[Investigation Discovery]] profiled the murder of Jason Sweeney on May 17, 2016, less than two weeks before the 13th anniversary of Sweeney's death.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}}
== Further reading == *{{cite book|last=Coia|first=Domenic|title=Biological Juvenile|url=http://prisonsfoundation.org/uploads/mem-biologicaljuv.pdf |date=2013-10-05|publisher=Unpublished book manuscript, posted on prisonsfoundation.org |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807215414/http://prisonsfoundation.org/uploads/mem-biologicaljuv.pdf|archive-date=2016-08-07|access-date=2016-05-23}} *{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Ali|title=Smells Like Teen Carnage: A Philly Comics Writer Turns a Fishtown Murder Into Grim Art|url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/arts-and-culture/smells_like_teen_carnage-38427929.html|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Weekly]]|date=2007-06-20 |access-date=2016-01-17}} *{{cite web|last=Ramsland|first=Katherine|title=The Unthinkable: Children Who Kill|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/weird/kids2/party_8.html|publisher=[[truTV]]|website=trutv.com|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326133038/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/weird/kids2/party_8.html|archive-date=2010-03-26|access-date=2016-01-17|df=}}

Nicola Saggio
[[Order of Minims|O.M.]] |birth_date={{Birth date|1650|1|6|df=y}} |death_date={{death date and age|1709|2|3|1650|1|6|df=y}} |feast_day=10 August |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholic Church]] |image= Riproduzione_quadro_di_San_Nicola_Saggio_da_Longobardi_esposto_a_Campora_San_Giovanni.JPG |imagesize= |caption= |birth_place=[[Longobardi, Calabria|Longobardi]], [[Calabria]], [[Italy]] |death_place=[[Rome]], [[Lazio]], [[Papal States]] |titles=Religious |beatified_date=17 September 1786 |beatified_place=[[Saint Peter's Basilica]], Papal States |beatified_by=[[Pope Pius VI]] |canonized_date=23 November 2014 |canonized_place=[[Saint Peter's Square]], [[Vatican City]] |canonized_by=[[Pope Francis]] |attributes={{unbulleted list|[[Crucifix]]|Minim habit}} |patronage=[[Nicolò Longobardo|Longobardi]] |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= |prayer= |prayer_attrib= }} [[Canonization|Saint]] '''Nicola Saggio''' was an [[Italian people|Italian]] [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] professed oblate of the [[Minim (religious order)|Order of Minims]]. He was [[beatification|beatified]] on 17 September 1786 and was [[Canonization|canonized]] as a saint of the Roman Catholic Church on 23 November 2014.Announcement during the consistory of 12 June 12, 2014 ==Life== Nicola Saggio was born on 6 January 1650 in [[Longobardi, Calabria|Longobardi]], a small town on the [[Tyrrhenian Sea|Tyrrhenian]] coast. His parents were Fulvio Saggio, a farmer, and Aurelia Saggio née Pizzini. He was the first of five children while the twins Antonio and Domenica followed and then Nicola and Muzio. He was [[baptized]] in the names of "Giovanni Battista Clemente"[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/90628 Santi e Beati] on 10 January 1650. His parents raised him with high moral and spiritual values and instilled in him a Christian education.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} He visited the convent of the [[Minim (religious order)|Minims]] which made him desire the religious life as his path in life. He was famous as a [[catechist]] in Longobardi and in Roman circles. A further change in his spiritual life was recorded in 1683 after a pilgrimage on foot to [[Loreto, Marche|Loreto]] to ask [[God]] – through the intercession of the [[Blessed Virgin Mary]] – for the liberation of [[Vienna]] from the [[Ottoman Empire|Turks]].P.A. Bellantonio, ''Nicola Saggio. Più in alto delle aquile'', ed. Postulazione generale dei Minimi, 1986 ==Sainthood== [[File:Fonte battesimale beato Nicola.jpg|thumb|left|170px|The [[baptismal font]] where St. Nicola Saggio was baptized.]] On 17 March 1771 he was made [[Venerable]] once [[Pope Clement XIV]] confirmed his life of [[heroic virtue]]. [[Pope Pius VI]] presided over the rite of beatification for the late oblate on 17 September 1786 in [[Saint Peter's Basilica]] after approving two miracles attributed to his intercession on 2 April 1786. After the beatification he was made the patron of Longobardi (his village). The third and final miracle for the canonization occurred in 1938 for a mason of Longobardi who fell from a scaffold without sustaining injuries. The diocesan investigation took place between 24 May 2008 and 15 June 2009; the process received the validation of the [[Congregation for the Causes of Saints]] on 11 March 2011 while the consulting medical board approved the miracle on 13 December 2012. Theologians voiced approval on 28 November 2013 while the C.C.S. also assented on 4 March 2014. [[Pope Francis]] canonized him as a saint on 23 November 2014 in [[Saint Peter's Square]] after approving the miracle on 3 April 2014. The [[postulator]] at the time of the canonization was the Rev. Ottavio Laino. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140812203900/http://www.sannicolasaggio.it/ San Nicola Saggio] {{it icon}} * [http://newsaints.faithweb.com/year/1709.htm Hagiography Circle] {{Canonization}} {{Subject bar |portal1= Biography |portal2= Catholicism |portal3= Italy}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saggio, Nicola}} [[Category:1650 births]] [[Category:1709 deaths]] [[Category:People from the Province of Cosenza]] [[Category:17th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:17th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:17th-century Roman Catholics]] [[Category:17th-century Italian people]] [[Category:18th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:18th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:18th-century Roman Catholics]] [[Category:18th-century Italian people]] [[Category:Canonizations by Pope Francis]] [[Category:Italian Roman Catholic saints]] [[Category:Italian Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Minims (religious order)]] [[Category:Venerated Catholics]] [[Category:Deaths in Rome]]

Van Amburgh]] | role = | years_active = c. 1824 - 1865 | known = | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | parents = | children = | weight = 15,000 pounds | height = 8 feet 11 inches | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} '''Old Hannibal''' (c. 1800 - May 7, 1865) was a famous 19th century Asiatic elephant that was part of [[Isaac A. Van Amburgh]]'s menagerie. ==History== Hannibal was brought to the United States as early as 1824 according to early sources,(22 June 1901). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2249&dat=19010622&id=BZY-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=sVkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4884,2896812 Answers], ''[[Boston Evening Transcript]]'' but at least by 1831. He was first called "Timour the Tartar" and renamed by Raymond, Weeks & Co. in 1833 as "War Elephant Hannibal".Kogan, Lee. [http://issuu.com/american_folk_art_museum/docs/folkart_30_3_fall2005/80 Quilt Connection], ''Folk Art'', p. 78-79 (Fall 2005) (article includes history of Hannibal as part of discussing a quilt with a square depicting Hannibal and his trainer from 1851-63, B. Frank Thomas) He was known for having "fits of fury",[https://books.google.com/books?id=KmYXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA25#v=onepage&q&f=false A Brief Biographical Sketch of I.A. Van Amburgh], pp. 25-28 (1860) and reportedly killed several people.(18 January 1882). [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85053157/1882-01-18/ed-1/seq-6/ Crazy Elephants], ''The River Press'' Around 1839, he engaged in a fight with Columbus, another huge elephant, in [[Algiers, New Orleans]]; Columbus also killed two men that day.[http://www.circushistory.org/Bandwagon/bw-1954Apr.htm A Circus Remembrance], ''Bandwagon'' (April–May 1954) (running story from 1869 edition of ''Cincinnati Chronicle'')Oswandel, J. Jacob. [https://books.google.com/books?id=LI4-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA28#v=onepage&q&f=false Notes on the Mexican War], p. 28-29 (1885) In June 1854, he escaped his keeper near [[Pawtucket, Rhode Island]] and ran many miles before being captured.(29 April 2010). [https://hsp.org/blogs/hidden-histories/lions-tigers-bears-o-my-no-rampaging-elephants-an-african-rhinos-escape-to-freedom-during-the-civil 'Lions & Tigers & Bears, O My?' NO: Rampaging Elephants & an African Rhino's Escape to Freedom during the Civil War!], Historical Society of Pennsylvania, Hidden History Blog And in November 1859, he caused a scene when he briefly escaped from captivity in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]], injuring one man and freeing other animals from their cages on his way.(5 November 1859). [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1859-11-05/ed-1/seq-2/ Tremendous Excitement - An Elephant Loose in the Streets], ''[[The Sun (New York)]]'', p. 2, col. 6 In October 1862, he killed a "partially deranged" man who irritated him in [[Caldwell, Ohio]], whereupon Van Amburgh had his tusks sawn off.(18 October 1862). [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2006.05.0600%3Aarticle%3D10 A man killed by the elephant Hannibal], ''Daily Dispatch'' One winter, Hannibal was wintered next to "Queen Anne", a female elephant from a different traveling circus unit, and it was said to be "a case of love at first sight," with mutual affection displayed between the elephants all winter. Hannibal became very depressed when they were parted in the spring, refusing to eat for eleven days (drinking only water and whiskey), and on the next day briefly escaping his fastenings in a rage.Nance, Susan. [https://books.google.com/books?id=k2DvAkBB7l4C Entertaining Elephants: Animal Agency and the Business of the American Circus] (2013)(12 November 1862). [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85026309/1862-11-12/ed-1/seq-1/ An Elephant on a Bender], ''Urbana Union'' ==Death== Hannibal died, perhaps from eating poison laurel, in Centerville, [[Bedford County, Pennsylvania]] (located in [[Cumberland Valley Township, Bedford County, Pennsylvania|Cumberland Valley Township]]),(22 December 1910). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19101222&id=rxUbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3EgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4528,5442163 Most Famous Elephants of Captivity - "Old Hannibal" Most Perfect Specimen of Species Ever Exhibited, Was in Class By Himself], ''[[Pittsburgh Press]]'' on May 7, 1865. He had lost his appetite and had become weak in the days prior to his death.(2 June 1865). [https://www.nytimes.com/1865/06/02/news/coroners-inquests.html Death of the Elephant Hannibal], ''[[The New York Times]]'' Originally his skeleton was offered to New York City to be displayed, which was declined. Hannibal was buried near where he died, but his bones were reportedly exhumed under the direction of H.V. Boyd to be sent to the [[Chicago Medical College]] in 1871, though it is unclear if the bones made it there.[http://www.circushistory.org/Query/Query11d.htm Circus History.org - including 1865 news reports], Retrieved 19 February 2014 According to a report on Hannibal's death in the ''Bedford Inquirer'' (May 17, 1865):
Hannibal was the largest animal ever exhibited on this continent. His height was eleven feet eight inches, and weight was ascertained to be 15,000 pounds, or seven and one-half tons. He consumed three hundred pounds of hay, three bushels of oats, and forty-six gallons of water per day. He was supposed to be in his sixty-fifth year at the time of his death. For thirty-six years he traversed this continent, at an average of 3,000 miles per year, the greatest curiosity ever exhibited to the wondering millions.(27 May 1865). Death of Hannibal, the Big Elephant, ''[[Brooklyn Daily Eagle]]'', p. 4 col. 1 (copy from ''Bedford Inquirer'')

His position was [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] and [[midfielder]].
During a league match against [[Pelita Bandung Raya]] on 21 April 2013, Rumaropen assaulted the referee, punching him in the face after he had awarded a penalty against Persiwa Wamena.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/soccer-dirty-tackle/dtotd-indonesian-referee-punched-face-awarding-penalty-143251403--sow.html | title=DTotD: Indonesian referee punched in the face after awarding penalty | accessdate=2013-04-23 | author=Bailey, Ryan}}</ref> The official left the field, bleeding from his torn lower lip, and Rumaropen was given a red card.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/VIDEO-Football-referee-gets-punched-in-face/tabid/415/articleID/295396/Default.aspx|work=3 News | title= Football referee gets punched in face| date=April 24, 2013}}</ref> As a result of the assault Rumaropen was banned for life by PSSI, the [[Football Association of Indonesia]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/indonesian-striker-gets-life-ban-for-punching-referee-1.263519 News | title=Indonesian striker gets life ban for punching referee | date=April 24, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130425103123/http://www.nst.com.my/latest/indonesian-striker-gets-life-ban-for-punching-referee-1.263519 | archivedate=April 25, 2013 | df= }}</ref>
Despite of the life ban, Ruparopen still played for Persiwa Wamena on Premier League after getting relegated from Super League that year.

{{speciesbox | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN|id=22681363 |title=''Dryocopus pileatus'' |assessor=BirdLife International |assessor-link=BirdLife International |version=2013.2 |year=2012 |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> | image = PileatedWoodpeckerFeedingonTree, crop.jpg | image2 = Pileated Woodpecker (9597212081), crop.jpg | image2_caption = male and female | genus = Dryocopus | species = pileatus | authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]]) | range_map = Pileated_Woodpecker-rangemap.gif | range_map_caption = {{legend|#02CB31| Range of ''D. pileatus''|outline=gray}} | synonyms = ''Picus pileatus'' {{small|Linnaeus, 1758}} }}
The '''pileated woodpecker''' (''Dryocopus pileatus'') is a [[woodpecker]] native to [[North America]]. This insectivorous bird is a mostly sedentary inhabitant of [[deciduous]] forests in eastern North America, the [[Great Lakes]], the [[boreal forest]]s of [[Canada]], and parts of the [[Pacific coast]]. It is the second-largest woodpecker on the continent, after the critically endangered — and possibly extinct — [[ivory-billed woodpecker]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ivory-Billed Woodpecker, Life History |url= https://www.allaboutbirds.org/guide/Ivory-billed_Woodpecker/lifehistory|website=The Cornell Lab of Ornithology; All About Birds |publisher=Cornell University|accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> The term "pileated" refers to the bird's prominent red crest, with the term from the [[Latin]] ''pileatus'' meaning "capped".<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/pileated_woodpecker |title= Pileated woodpecker|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date=}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:111 Pileated Woodpecker, b.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Plate 111 of the'' [[Birds of America (book)|Birds of America]]'' by [[John James Audubon]], depicting pileated woodpeckers (1 ♀, 3 ♂♂)]] Adults are {{convert|40|to|49|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, span {{convert|66|to|75|cm|in|abbr=on}} across the wings, and weigh {{convert|250|to|400|g|oz|abbr=on}}, with an average weight of {{convert|300|g|oz|abbr=on}}. Each wing measures {{convert|21.4|to|25.3|cm|in|abbr=on}}, the tail measures {{convert|14.0|to|17.4|cm|in|abbr=on}}, the bill is {{convert|4.1|to|6.0|cm|in|abbr=on}} and the tarsus measures {{convert|3.1| to|3.8|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Winkler">''Woodpeckers: An Identification Guide to the Woodpeckers of the World'' by Hans Winkler, David A. Christie & David Nurney. Houghton Mifflin (1995), {{ISBN|978-0395720431}}</ref> They are mainly black with a red [[Crest (feathers)|crest]], and have a white line down the sides of the throat. They show white on the wings in flight. The flight of these birds is strong and direct, but undulates in the way characteristic of woodpeckers. Adult males have a red line from the bill to the throat, in adult females these are black.<ref name=NW>[http://www.nhptv.org/NatureWorks/pileatedwoodpecker.htm Pileated Woodpecker], Nature Works</ref> Two species found in the [[Old World]], the [[White-bellied woodpecker|white-bellied]] and [[black woodpecker]]s, are closely related and occupy the same [[ecological niche]] in their respective ranges that the pileated occupies in North America.<ref name="Winkler"/> The only North American birds of similar plumage and size are the [[ivory-billed woodpecker]] of the [[southeastern United States]] and [[Cuba]], and the related [[imperial woodpecker]] of [[Mexico]]. However, unlike the pileated, both of those species are extremely rare, if not [[List of extinct birds|extinct]]. Most reports of the ivory-billed woodpecker are believed to be erroneous reports of the far more common pileated.
===Subspecies=== Up to four subspecies of pileated woodpeckers have been recognized historically. However, many authors only recognize two subspecies, the southernly ''D. p.'' subsp. ''pileatus'' and the northerly ''D. p.'' subsp. ''abieticola'', and the differences between the other two subspecies other than range are not well described. Generally, pileated woodpeckers follow [[Bergmann's rule]] being smaller and more compact in the south (''D. p.'' subsp. ''pileatus'') and larger in the north (''D. p.'' subsp. ''abieticola''). The ranges of the potential four subspecies are described below.<ref name="Winkler"/><ref>[http://www.prbo.org/calpif/htmldocs/species/conifer/piwoacct.html]</ref>
*Southern pileated woodpecker (''D. p.'' subsp. ''pileatus'') – the southeastern U.S., except [[Florida]] *Northern pileated woodpecker (''D. p.'' subsp. ''abieticola'') – from the [[Canadian Prairies]] provinces east through [[Eastern Canada]] and the northern United States *Florida pileated woodpecker (''D. p.'' subsp. ''floridanus'') – the [[Florida peninsula]] and [[Florida Keys]] *Western pileated woodpecker (''D. p.'' subsp. ''picinus'') – western North America
==Distribution and habitat== Their breeding habitat is forested areas across Canada, the eastern United States, and parts of the [[Pacific]] coast. This bird favors mature forests and heavily wooded parks. They specifically prefer [[mesic habitat]]s with large, mature hardwood trees, often being found in large tracts of forest. However, they also inhabit smaller woodlots as long as they have a scattering of tall trees. Efforts to restore woodland by removing invasive honeysuckle and buckthorn seem to benefit them, as the removal of brush and shrubbery facilitates their foraging on the ground and in the lower stratum.<ref name="garc">{{cite web |last1=Garcia |first1=Evan |title=More Pileated Woodpeckers: Emerald Ash Borer or Healthier Habitat? |url=https://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2016/04/07/more-pileated-woodpeckers-emerald-ash-borer-or-healthier-habitat |publisher=Chicago Tonight |date = 7 April 2016 |accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
==Behavior== [[File:Pileated Woodpecker male.jpg|thumb|upright|Male drilling in wood]] These birds mainly eat insects, especially [[carpenter ant]]s and wood-boring beetle larvae. They also eat fruits, nuts, and berries, including [[poison ivy]] berries.<ref>Beal, F.E. 1895. Preliminary report on the food of Woodpeckers. United States Department of Agriculture. Division of Ornithology and Mammalogy. Bulletin No. 7. Government Printing Office. Washington, District of Columbia. p. 32.</ref> Pileated woodpeckers often chip out large and roughly rectangular holes in trees while searching out insects, especially ant colonies.<ref name=NW/> They also lap up ants by reaching with their long tongues into crevices. They are self-assured on the vertical surfaces of large trees, but can seem awkward while feeding on small branches and vines. Pileated woodpeckers may also forage on or near the ground, especially around fallen, dead trees, which can contain a variety of insect life. They may forage around the sides of human homes or even cars, and can occasionally be attracted to suet-type feeders. Although they are less likely feeder visitors than smaller woodpeckers, pileateds may regularly be attracted to them in areas experiencing harsh winter conditions.
Usually, pileated woodpeckers excavate their large nests in the cavities of dead trees. Woodpeckers make such large holes in dead trees that the holes can cause a small tree to break in half. The roost of a pileated woodpecker usually has multiple entrance holes. Pileated woodpeckers raise their young every year in a hole in a tree. In April, the hole made by the male attracts a female for mating and raising their young. Once the brood is raised, the pileated woodpeckers abandon the hole and do not use it the next year. When abandoned, these holes — made similarly by all woodpeckers — provide good homes in future years for many forest song birds and a wide variety of other animals. Owls and tree-nesting ducks may largely rely on holes made by pileateds in which to lay their nests. Even mammals such as raccoons may use them. Other woodpeckers and smaller birds such as wrens may be attracted to pileated holes to feed on the insects found in them. Ecologically, the entire woodpecker family is important to the well being of many other bird species. The pileated woodpecker also nests in boxes about {{convert|4.6|m|ft|abbr=on}} off the ground. {{listen|filename=Dryocopus pileatus.ogg|title=call}} {{listen|filename=Dryocopus pileatus - Pileated Woodpecker - XC71727.ogg|title=display drum (a short burst of 10 taps)}} A pileated woodpecker pair stays together on its territory all year round and is not migratory. They defend the territory in all seasons, but tolerate floaters during the winter.<ref>[http://canadianbiodiversity.mcgill.ca/english/species/birds/birdpages/dry_pil.htm Pileated Woodpecker], Canadian Biodiversity Web Site</ref> When clashing with conspecifics, they engage in much chasing, calling, striking with the wings, and jabbing with the bill. Drumming is most commonly to proclaim a territory, and hollow trees are often used to make the most resonant sound possible. The display drum consists of a burst of 11 to 30 taps delivered in less than a second.<ref name="twice">{{cite web |title=Pileated Woodpecker tapping twice |url= http://www.birds.cornell.edu/ivory/multimedia/sounds/listening/pw |website=Big Woods Conservation Partnership |publisher=Cornell University |date=2018 |accessdate=20 August 2018}}</ref>
Pileated woodpeckers have been observed to move to another site if any eggs have fallen out of the nest — a rare habit in birds. The cavity is unlined except for wood chips. Both parents incubate three to five eggs for 12 to 16 days. The average clutch size is four per nest. The young may take a month to fledge.<ref>[http://talkaboutwildlife.ca/profile/?s=191 Pileated Woodpecker], Talk about Wildlife {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210329/http://talkaboutwildlife.ca/profile/?s=191 |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> The oldest known pileated woodpecker was 12 years and 11 months old. Predators at the nest can include [[American marten]]s, [[weasel]]s, [[squirrel]]s, [[rat snake]]s, and [[gray fox]]es. Free-flying adults have fewer predators, but can be taken in some numbers by [[Cooper's hawk]]s, [[northern goshawk]]s, [[red-tailed hawk]]s, [[great horned owl]]s, and [[barred owl]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pileatedwoodpeckercentral.com/information.htm |accessdate=June 20, 2012| title=Pileated Woodpecker |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717065851/http://www.pileatedwoodpeckercentral.com/information.htm |archivedate=July 17, 2012 }}</ref>
==Status== The pileated woodpecker occupies a large range and is quite adaptable. Its ability to survive in many wooded habitat types has allowed the species to survive human habitation of North America much better than the more specialized ivory-billed woodpecker. Pileated woodpeckers have a large population size, and despite being nonmigratory, are protected under the U.S. Migratory Bird Act. While the large birds control many insect populations, especially tree beetles, that may otherwise experience outbreaks, some people may consider them harmful if found on their property due to the considerable damage that pileated woodpeckers can do to trees and homes.
